block.p: On Way to See Putin, Bush Offers Two-Sided Message President Bush, stopping in the Czech Republic on his way to the Group of 8 meeting, delivered a two-pronged message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, chiding him for derailing democratic reforms while assuring him that he has nothing to fear from a missile defense system in Europe.

Abbas Warns of Civil War The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, said that the Palestinians are on the brink of civil war and that their internal battles are as dangerous to their welfare as has been Israeli occupation, if not more so.

ETA Calls Off Cease-Fire Spain was bracing for fresh attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA after the group called off a 15-month-old cease-fire and vowed to resume its battle for an independent Basque nation.

NATO Kills 20 on Taliban Boat The Afghan Defense Ministry said that a boat full of fleeing Taliban fighters had been fired upon by NATO helicopters and sunk in the Helmand River in Afghanistan. Between 20 and 30 guerrillas drowned, said a ministry spokesman.
Huge Cyclone in Arabian Sea Oman and Iran girded for heavy flooding and winds as the strongest cyclone ever recorded by scientists in the northwestern Arabian Sea began to hit coastlines.

U.N. Embraces New U.S. Envoy Zalmay Khalilzad, the new American ambassador to the United Nations, has been welcomed with open arms by his fellow delegates since he arrived six months ago. One reason is that he strikes people as so different from John R. Bolton, the combative former ambassador.

Libby Is Sentenced In C.I.A. Leak Case I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney and one of the principal architects of President Bush's foreign policy, was sentenced to 30 months in prison for lying in a C.I.A. leak investigation.

Clinton Under Fire for Remarks Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is under attack for saying America is safer now than before 9/11 -- contrary to a popular line of argument among some Democratic officials and liberals.
Power Plant Runs on Manure A power plant that burns turkey litter, manure mixed with farm-animal bedding like wood chips, to produce electricity is the first of its kind in the country.

Findings on Plane Crash Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said that they thought mechanical difficulties caused a plane with four members of a medical team and two pilots to crash while racing organs from Milwaukee to Michigan. A14
Egyptian Fights Deportation An Egyptian Coptic Christian who was permitted to stay in the United States because of the threat of torture back home is now fighting deportation.

Warnings Against Tuberculosis Tuberculosis may reach the point where most new cases are resistant to many drugs unless far greater efforts are made now to stop the spread of the infection, World Health Organization officials said.

Convicted of Corruption, Ex-Officials Surrender Two deposed Brooklyn officials -- former Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., once the borough's powerful Democratic leader, and Gerald P. Garson, a former State Supreme Court justice -- surrendered for sentencing on corruption charges. B1

Campaign Finance Pact Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and New York City Council leaders have agreed on a major overhaul of the city's campaign finance laws, intended to enhance the power of small donors and reduce the influence of those who do business with the city, including real estate developers. B1

Avandia's Safety Challenged Several diabetes experts said that the data that was released online by GlaxoSmithKline, the maker of diabetes medicine, Avandia, did nothing to alleviate their concerns about the drug's heart risks. Questions about Avandia's safety are the subject of a Congressional hearing.

Grocery Chain Sale Blocked The Federal Trade Commission said it would attempt to block sale of Wild Oaks Market to a rival, Whole Foods Market, arguing that the merger would lead to higher prices for natural and organic products in markets where the two now compete.

Clear Sign From the Fed The stock market stumbled as Wall Street grasped that the Federal Reserve is in no hurry to lower interest rates. The sell-off began after yields on the 10-year Treasury note, which is the benchmark for interest rates, inched toward 5 percent. C3
Craig Thomas A Republican senator from Wyoming who combined a deep love of Western rural life with a 23-year public career in his home state and Washington, he was 74. A21
